title: World's most asked questions: how can I get rid of the hiccups?

multiple-choice.question: What is a hiccup?

options.label: A
options.text: A sudden contraction of the diaphragm that causes a person to breathe in quickly.

options.label: B
options.text: A sudden contraction of the diaphragm that causes a person to breathe out slowly.

options.label: C
options.text: A sudden contraction of the diaphragm that causes a person to make a loud noise.

options.label: D
options.text: A sudden contraction of the diaphragm that causes a person to feel dizzy.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of stimulating the vagus nerve to get rid of hiccups?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase the level of carbon dioxide in the bloodstream.

options.label: B
options.text: To distract the vagus nerve from constantly zapping the diaphragm.

options.label: C
options.text: To decrease the level of oxygen in the bloodstream.

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the level of sugar in the bloodstream.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way to increase the level of carbon dioxide in the bloodstream to get rid of hiccups?

options.label: A
options.text: By drinking a tall glass of water.

options.label: C
options.text: By gulping down a teaspoon of sugar.

options.label: D
options.text: By breathing into a paper bag.

multiple-choice.question: According to the survey, what percentage of people prefer to hold their breath to relieve hiccups?
What is the name of the series that SciShow is working on to answer the most popular questions searched for on the internet?

title: Architecture adventure: Crash Course Kids

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The amount of noise planned to be made inside the treehouse.

multiple-choice.question: What is the final step in the engineering process that the engineer is using to solve the problem?

options.label: A
options.text: Defining the problem and identifying the requirements.

options.label: B
options.text: Weighing options and choosing the best design.

options.label: C
options.text: Building the prototype and testing it.

options.label: D
options.text: Isolating the variables and conducting useful trials.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: A Native American Civil Rights Activist

What was Malcolm X's name before he joined the Nation of Islam?
What was the phrase often associated with Malcolm X?
Where was Malcolm X assassinated?

title: Can you solve the worldâ€™s most evil wizard riddle? - Dan Finkel

multiple-choice.question: The evil wizard MoldeVort starts in one corner of a 5x5 chessboard. You have a few minutes to choose four distinct positive whole numbers. What is the problem you're trying to solve?

options.label: A
options.text: Keeping MoldeVort trapped on the board using the fewest possible moves.

options.label: B
options.text: Finding the shortest path to move MoldeVort to the center of the board.

options.label: C
options.text: Choosing four numbers that will keep MoldeVort trapped long enough for help to arrive.

options.label: D
options.text: Determining the optimal strategy to defeat MoldeVort in a game of chess.

multiple-choice.question: The Pythagorean Theorem states that the squares of the sides of a right triangle add up to the square of its hypotenuse. What is the most famous Pythagorean triple mentioned in the transcript?
The chessboard is very symmetrical, and the problem can be reduced to just three types of spaces. What are the three types of spaces on the board?

options.label: D
options.text: Blue, red, and midpoints of the sides

multiple-choice.question: The numbers 2 and 4 are problematic because they could take MoldeVort to an orange space or an inside space. What is the status of the orange spaces on the board?

options.label: A
options.text: Orange spaces are good for us, because they can help keep MoldeVort trapped.

options.label: B
options.text: Orange spaces are bad for us, because they could take MoldeVort to an inside space or off the board.

options.label: C
options.text: Orange spaces are neutral, and they don't affect the game.

options.label: D
options.text: Orange spaces are irrelevant, and they can be ignored.

multiple-choice.question: The four numbers 1, 3, 4, and 5 might work to keep MoldeVort trapped on the board. What is the reasoning behind choosing these numbers?

options.label: A
options.text: These numbers are the smallest possible numbers, and they are guaranteed to work.

options.label: B
options.text: These numbers are the most difficult numbers to solve, and they will challenge MoldeVort.

options.label: C
options.text: These numbers have a special property that allows us to keep MoldeVort trapped, such as diagonal moves.

options.label: D
options.text: These numbers are arbitrary, and we chose them at random.

title: Learn to use suffixes -le -al -el with the Singing Nun | Educational song

multiple-choice.question: What is the most common letter used in words that end with the "le" sound?
What is a good rule of thumb to follow when deciding whether to use "l" or "el" in words that end with the "le" sound?

options.label: A
options.text: Try using "el" first, and if it doesn't look right, try "l".

options.label: B
options.text: Try using "l" first, and if it doesn't look right, try "el".

options.label: C
options.text: Always use "el" in words that end with the "le" sound.

options.label: D
options.text: Always use "l" in words that end with the "le" sound.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following words are exceptions to the rule that "l" is used after the letters m, n, r, v, and w?
How can you remember which letters "l" is used after (m, n, r, v, and w)?

options.label: A
options.text: By thinking of a camel with an m, a tunnel with an n, and a travel with a beanie.

options.label: B
options.text: By thinking of a camel with an m, a tunnel with an n, and a travel with a v.

options.label: C
options.text: By thinking of a camel with an m, a tunnel with an n, and a travel with a w.

options.label: D
options.text: By thinking of a camel with an m, a tunnel with an n, and a travel with a r.

multiple-choice.question: What is a good way to remember the exceptions to the rule that "l" is used after the letters m, n, r, v, and w?

options.label: A
options.text: By thinking of a signal with a personal animal.

options.label: B
options.text: By thinking of a camel with a broken rule.

options.label: C
options.text: By thinking of a tunnel with a beanie.

options.label: D
options.text: By thinking of a travel with a v.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for three consonants that make a gang?
What is one benefit of finding a gang of three in a word?

options.label: B
options.text: It helps you break the word into smaller chunks

options.label: C
options.text: It makes the word easier to memorize

options.label: D
options.text: It makes the word to sound more complex

What is the purpose of learning about the different gangs of three?

options.text: To help you break words into smaller chunks

title: How do you know if you have a virus? - Cella Wright

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of PCR (polymerase chain reaction) testing in diagnosing viral infections?

options.label: A
options.text: To identify the genetic material of the virus in the body.

options.label: B
options.text: To amplify genetic information to large enough quantities for detection.

options.label: C
options.text: To develop a vaccine against the virus.

options.label: D
options.text: To identify the symptoms of the virus.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of IgM antibodies in diagnosing viral infections?

options.label: A
options.text: They circulate for an extended period after infection.

options.label: B
options.text: They are the most abundant class of antibodies.

options.label: C
options.text: They are first produced in response to a new infection.

options.label: D
options.text: They are unreliable in diagnosing current infections.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of reverse transcription in PCR testing?

options.label: A
options.text: To make a strand of complementary DNA from viral RNA.

options.label: B
options.text: To amplify genetic information to large enough quantities for detection.

options.label: C
options.text: To identify the genetic material of the virus in the body.

options.label: D
options.text: To develop a vaccine against the virus.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between PCR and immunoassay testing in diagnosing viral infections?

options.label: A
options.text: PCR targets the virus's genetic material, while immunoassay targets virus-specific antibodies.

options.label: B
options.text: PCR is used to diagnose current infections, while immunoassay is used to diagnose past infections.

options.label: C
options.text: PCR is more accurate than immunoassay, while immunoassay is more efficient than PCR.

options.label: D
options.text: PCR is used to develop a vaccine against the virus, while immunoassay is used to identify symptoms.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential use of blood plasma from individuals who have developed immunity to a virus?

options.label: A
options.text: To develop a vaccine against the virus.

options.label: B
options.text: To treat people who are currently fighting the virus.

options.label: C
options.text: To identify the genetic material of the virus in the body.

title: Why do bats carry so many diseases? (like coronavirus)

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following viruses have surfaced in humans in the last 50 years and are carried by bats?

options.label: B
options.text: Ebola, SARS, Nipah, Hendra, and Marburg

multiple-choice.question: What is a possible reason why bats may carry more human-killing diseases than other animals?

options.label: A
options.text: Bats are more social animals, which helps viruses spread between individuals and species.

options.label: B
options.text: Bats are less social animals, which reduces the spread of viruses.

options.label: C
options.text: Bats are more aggressive animals, which increases the spread of viruses.

options.label: D
options.text: Bats are less aggressive animals, which reduces the spread of viruses.

multiple-choice.question: What is a possible reason why bats are resilient to infection?

options.label: A
options.text: Bats have a strong immune system.

options.label: B
options.text: Bats have a weak immune system.

options.label: C
options.text: Bats produce a lot of energy for flight, which also produces DNA-damaging waste products.

options.label: D
options.text: Bats produce a lot of energy for flight, but it doesn't produce any DNA-damaging waste products.

multiple-choice.question: What may happen to viruses when bats take to the air?

options.label: A
options.text: They become more active and spread quickly.

options.label: B
options.text: They become less active and spread slowly.

options.label: C
options.text: They are killed by the high temperatures inside the bats.

options.label: D
options.text: They are able to survive the heat and become more resilient.

multiple-choice.question: What should humans do to minimize the risk of disease transmission from bats?

options.label: A
options.text: We should try to control the spread of diseases carried by bats.

options.label: B
options.text: We should leave bats alone and try to control the spread of diseases carried by other animals.

options.label: C
options.text: We should try to eliminate bats from our environment.

options.label: D
options.text: We should try to capture bats and study them in a laboratory.

title: Adding '-ed' | Past tense verbs

multiple-choice.question: What does Ed need to travel into the past?
What is special about the word "happen"?
What happens when Ed adds "ed" to the end of a verb?

options.label: B
options.text: The verb becomes a verb that happened in the past

multiple-choice.question: What type of words can be used by Ed to travel back in time?
What did Ed do hard today or yesterday?

title: What is a coronavirus? - Elizabeth Cox

multiple-choice.question: Where did scientists finally find the source of a deadly new virus that caused an epidemic of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in 2003?

options.label: A
options.text: In the bats of Shitou Cave in China

options.label: B
options.text: In the caves of the Amazon rainforest

options.label: C
options.text: In the bats of the caves in the Himalayas

options.label: D
options.text: In the bats of the caves in Africa

multiple-choice.question: What is a key feature of coronaviruses that makes them more stable and have a slower mutation rate than other RNA viruses?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a unique enzyme that checks for replication errors and corrects mistakes

options.label: B
options.text: They have a large number of genes

multiple-choice.question: How do coronaviruses transmit best?

options.label: A
options.text: In open spaces with good ventilation

options.label: B
options.text: In enclosed spaces where people are close together

options.label: C
options.text: Through direct contact with an infected person

multiple-choice.question: Why is the slow mutation rate of coronaviruses a promising sign when it comes to disarming them?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes it easier for the virus to infect new hosts

options.label: B
options.text: It makes it harder for our immune systems to recognize the virus

options.label: C
options.text: It means that our immune systems, drugs, and vaccines might be able to recognize the virus for longer after infection

options.label: D
options.text: It means that the virus is more likely to be resistant to antiviral drugs

multiple-choice.question: Why haven't there been any approved treatments or vaccines for coronaviruses, despite the existence of several coronaviruses that cause disease in humans?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are too complex to understand

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are too difficult to study

options.label: C
options.text: Because scientists haven't focused on treating the ones that cause colds

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not a significant threat to human health

title: Fabulous food chains

multiple-choice.question: What is a food chain?

options.label: A
options.text: A model that shows how energy flows between non-living things.

options.label: B
options.text: A model that shows how energy flows between living things in an ecosystem.

options.label: C
options.text: A system that shows how plants and animals interact with each other.

options.label: D
options.text: A model that shows how the Sun's energy is transferred to the Earth.

multiple-choice.question: Where does the energy in a food chain start?

options.label: A
options.text: With the plants in the ecosystem.

options.label: B
options.text: With the animals in the ecosystem.

multiple-choice.question: What do plants use the Sun's energy to create?

options.label: A
options.text: Chemical energy that is transferred to animals.

options.label: B
options.text: Physical energy that is transferred to animals.

options.label: C
options.text: Chemical energy that is used to grow and develop.

options.label: D
options.text: Physical energy that is used to move and grow.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the energy in a food chain as animals eat plants and other animals?

options.label: A
options.text: The energy is transferred to the Earth.

options.label: B
options.text: The energy is transferred to the Sun.

options.label: C
options.text: The energy is transferred up the food chain.

options.label: D
options.text: The energy is lost in the ecosystem.

multiple-choice.question: What is an ecosystem?

options.label: A
options.text: A system that shows how plants and animals interact with each other.

options.label: B
options.text: A self-contained collection of different things that all work together as a whole.

options.label: C
options.text: A system that shows how the Sun's energy is transferred to the Earth.

options.label: D
options.text: A system that shows how energy flows between non-living things.

title: Why don't haircuts hurt?

multiple-choice.question: What do nerves have in common with muscles?

options.label: A
options.text: They are both types of body parts that can be seen under a microscope.

options.label: B
options.text: They are both types of body parts that can be found all over the inside of the body.

options.label: C
options.text: They are both types of body parts that have a special job to do.

options.label: D
options.text: They are both types of body parts that can be touched.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the biggest jobs that nerves have in the body?

options.label: B
options.text: To help us sense the world around us.

multiple-choice.question: Why don't fingernails and toenails hurt when they are cut?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are made of a special material that is pain-free.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they don't have nerves in them.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are too small to feel pain.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not a part of the body.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when something touches the skin?

options.label: C
options.text: The nerves get activated, and messages are sent to the brain.

multiple-choice.question: Why does the brain need to decode the messages sent by the nerves?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it needs to understand what the nerves are saying.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it needs to send the messages to other parts of the body.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it needs to combine the information with other information it can get.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it needs to make the messages stronger.

title: Why is my leg asleep?

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the nerves in your arm or leg when you sit in one position for a while?

options.label: A
options.text: They get more blood and start working better.

options.label: B
options.text: They get less blood and start working poorly.

options.label: C
options.text: They stay the same and don't get affected.

options.label: D
options.text: They get damaged and stop working.

multiple-choice.question: Why do you get a pins and needles feeling when you wake up a numb arm or leg?

options.label: A
options.text: Because your nerves are tired and need a rest.

options.label: B
options.text: Because your nerves are getting used to having enough blood again.

options.label: C
options.text: Because your nerves are a little bit confused and sending mixed signals to your brain.

options.label: D
options.text: Because your nerves are damaged and can't work properly.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why you get numbness or tingling in your arm or leg?

options.label: A
options.text: Because you're not eating enough food.

options.label: B
options.text: Because you're not drinking enough water.

options.label: C
options.text: Because you're pressing on the blood vessels and making them smaller.

options.label: D
options.text: Because you're not getting enough sleep.

multiple-choice.question: What can you do to help your nerves get back to normal when you have pins and needles?

options.label: A
options.text: You can try to ignore the feeling and hope it goes away.

options.label: B
options.text: You can shake around the arm or leg to help the blood get flowing again.

options.label: C
options.text: You can try to move your body in different positions to relieve the pressure.

options.label: D
options.text: You can try to massage the affected area to get the blood flowing.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it called "pins and needles" when you have numbness or tingling in your arm or leg?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it feels like you're getting poked with pins.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it feels like you're getting needles injected into your skin.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it's a medical term that describes the sensation.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it's a figure of speech that describes the feeling.

title: Human, capital & natural resources for kids | Types of resources

multiple-choice.question: What is a resource?

options.label: B

multiple-choice.question: What are capital resources?

options.label: A
options.text: Goods that are made and used to provide a service.

options.label: C
options.text: Things that are found on earth and can be used by people.

options.label: D
options.text: Tools and equipment needed to make goods.

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: Where did the bear find himself after being swept along by a great river?

options.label: A
options.text: In a new forest with many great climbing spots

options.label: B
options.text: In a forest with many great berry feasts

options.label: C
options.text: In a forest with many great mud pits

options.label: D
options.text: In a forest with many great scratching trees

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: A

options.label: C
